title: 廉价技术的力量：从钉子说起
content:
Nearly 2,000 years ago, as the Romans began to pull out of Scotland, they leftbehind a curious treasure: 10 tons of nails, nearly a million of the things. The nail hoardwas discovered in 1960 in a four-metre-deep pit covered by two metres of gravel.Why had the Romans buried a million nails? The likely explanation is that thewithdrawal was rushed, and they didn't want the local Caledonians getting their handson 10 tons of weapon-grade iron. The Romans buried the nails so deep that they wouldnot be discovered for almost two millennia.
 Later civilisations would value the skilled blacksmith's labour in a nail even morethan the raw material. As Roma Agrawal explains in her new delightful book Nuts andBols, carly 17th-century Virginians would sometimes bur down their homes if theywere planning to relocate. This was an attempt to recover the valuable nails, whichcould be reused after sifting the ashes. The idea that one might burn down an entirehouse just to reclaim the nails underlines how scarce, costly and valuable thesimple-sceming technology was.
The price of nails fell by 90% between the late 1700s and mid-1900s, as economistDanicl Sichel points out in a research paper. According to Sichel, although the fallingprice of nails was driven partly by chcaper iron and cheaper energy, most of the creditgoes to nail manufacturers who simply found more cfficient ways to turm steel into nails.Nails themsclves have changed over the ycars, but Sichel studied them becausethey haven't changed much. Roman lamps and Roman chariots are very different fromLED strips and sports cars,but Roman nails are still clearly nails. It would be absurd totry to track the changing price of sports cars since 1695, but to ask the same question ofnails makes perfect sense.
 I make no apology for being obsessed by a particular feature of these objects: theirprice. I am an economist, after all. After writing two books about the history ofinventions, one thing I've leamt is that while it is the enchantingly sophisticatedtechnologies that get all the hype, it's the cheap technologies that change the world.The Gutenberg printing press transformed civilisation not by changing the nature ofwriting but by changing its cost-and it would have achieved little without a parallelcollapse in the price of surfaces to write on, thanks to an often-overlooked technologycalled paper. Solar panels had few niche uses until they became cheap; now they aretransforming the global energy system.

questions.explanation: 文章第二段提到罗马人撤退时不想让当地人（Caledonians）得到这些铁资源，因为铁在当时是武器级的材料。

questions.prompt: The example of early 17th-century Virginians is used to

options.A: highlight the thriftiness of early American colonists.
options.B: illustrate the high status of blacksmiths in that period.
options.C: contrast the attitudes of different civilisations towards nails.
options.D: show the preciousness of nail-making technology at that time.

questions.explanation: 文章第三段通过弗吉尼亚人搬家时甚至烧掉房子来回收钉子的例子，强调了当时这种简单技术（钉子）是多么稀缺和珍贵。

questions.prompt: What played the major role in lowering the price of nails after the late 1700s?
questions.explanation: 第四段指出，虽然铁和能源价格下降有一定贡献，但大部分功劳归于制造商找到了更高效的制造方式，即生产力的提高。

questions.prompt: It can be learned from Paragraph 5 that nails

options.B: have remained basically the same since Roman times.
options.C: are less studied than other everyday products.
options.D: are one of the world’s most significant inventions.

questions.explanation: 第五段明确提到作者研究钉子是因为它们“没怎么改变过”，并对比说古罗马的钉子至今依然能一眼看出是钉子。

questions.prompt: Which of the following best summarises the last two paragraphs?

options.A: Cheap technologies bring about revolutionary change.
options.B: Technological innovation is integral to economic success.
options.C: Technology defines people’s understanding of the world.
options.D: Sophisticated technologies develop from small inventions.

questions.explanation: 最后两段的核心观点是：虽然高精尖技术能博取眼球，但真正改变世界的是那些变便宜了的技术（如纸张、廉价后的太阳能电池板）。
